abstract.text: The complete list of properties and methods implemented by accessible elements.
Indicates whether the provided selector can be invoked on the element.
Returns the substring for the specified range.
Returns the attributed substring for the specified range of characters.
Returns the Rich Text Format (RTF) data that describes the specified range of characters.
Returns the rectangle enclosing the specified range of characters.
Returns the line number for the line holding the specified character index.
Returns the range of characters for the glyph that includes the specified character.
Returns a range of characters that all have the same style as the specified character.
Returns the range of characters in the specified line.
Returns the range of characters for the glyph at the specified point.
Values that indicate the sort direction of a column.
The cell at the specified column and row.
Converts the provided point in screen coordinates to a point in the layout area’s coordinate system.
Converts the provided size in screen coordinates to a size in the layout area’s coordinate system.
Converts the provided point in the layout area’s coordinates to a point in the screen’s coordinate system.
Converts the provided size in the layout area’s coordinates to a size in the screen’s coordinate system.
Values that indicate the marker type of an element.
Values that indicate the unit values of a ruler or layout area.
Cancels the current operation.
Simulates pressing Return in the element.
Decrements the element’s value.
Deletes the element’s value.
Increments the element’s value.
Selects the element.
Simulates clicking the element.
Brings this window to the front.
Displays the element’s alternate UI.
Returns to the element’s original UI.
Displays this menu element.
Returns a new notification object with a specified name and object.
An array of elements that are associated with the notification.
The announcement, as a localized string.
A priority level that can help an assistive app determine how to handle the corresponding notification.
The name of the notification.
The key used in the user info dictionary for notifications.
A data type for notification priority levels.
Values that indicate the orientation of elements, such as scroll bars and split views.
Values for specifying the priority level of a notification.
The type of objects that accessibility elements represent.
Specialized object subtypes that accessibility elements represent.
The keys in a posted accessibility notification's dictionary.
Make your app more accessible to users with disabilities by adding accessibility features.
Improve navigation in your app by using keyboard shortcuts and accessibility containers.
The complete list of properties and methods implemented by accessible elements.
A set of methods that support accessibility in a UI that changes dynamically—usually in response to mouse-hover events.
Notifications alert accessibility clients to changes in the user interface’s state.
Additional accessibility methods organized by getter and setter.

inlineContent.text: In general, your custom user interface elements should not adopt this protocol. Instead, select the role-specific protocol—such as
, or
—that best matches your element’s behavior.
Many AppKit classes already adopt the
protocol by default. In particular,
and

provide a default implementation for all the properties and methods listed in this protocol. However, if you create a custom subclass that adopts one of the role-specific protocols, the compiler may ask you to reimplement some of the protocol’s accessor or action methods. By forcing you to reimplement these methods, the compiler ensures your custom subclass provides accurate information to the accessibility clients.
If your custom user interface element does not inherit from
(or one of the other accessibility-enabled AppKit classes), subclass the

class instead. This class manages many of the details required to work with accessibility clients successfully. You also need to implement all the properties and methods from your user interface element’s role-specific protocol—as well as any additional properties and methods you may need to use to further customize your element’s behavior.
You can further customize any user interface elements by freely implementing any of the other properties or methods listed in the

protocol. You do not need to adopt any particular protocol to make these properties and methods available to the accessibility client. As soon as your element is accessibility enabled, the system automatically uses any of the
properties and methods that you have implemented.
If a user interface element inherits from

(or one of the other accessibility-enabled AppKit classes), you can also customize it by simply setting the appropriate properties. Often, you can fine tune how an accessibility client interacts with your element without creating a custom subclass.
Sometimes, however, it makes more sense to override the property’s accessor methods. If you override the getter for a property declared in the

protocol, the system lets accessibility clients call your getter. This can be particularly useful when managing dynamic properties, because you can calculate their current value on demand instead of trying to update the property in response to a change.
If you override the setter for a property, by default the system lets accessibility clients both read and modify that property. For example, you can override the setter for a control’s
property, letting users modify the control’s value through an accessibility client.
You can further control which accessor methods the accessibility client can use by overriding
. Return
if the accessibility client can call the selector; otherwise,
